channel.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
channel.description: What would I need to type into a shortcut to get it to shutdown the computer. I have tried "shutdown /i" at school. It opened up a cmd prompt and then immediatly closed it. Is there another command that would get the computer to shutdown or is there an alternative batch file that would get the computer to shut down.

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @redragonje65 redragonje65
item.description:
@redragonje65 wrote:

thx for the file. the problem is that the school computers don’t allow access to the C drive. But that isn’t a problem because the icon on the desktop is deletable. So it makes everything easier. I still have doubts that the shutdown command will work because of access restrictions. The earlist chance I have to test this would be on friday. I’ll post an update on how it goes. maybe is screenshots.

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @redragonje65 redragonje65
item.description:
@redragonje65 wrote:

Delete it and then replace it with the shortcut. I tried, on my computer at school, creating a shortcut with the location as “shutdown -s -t 10 -c haha” but all that came up was a Cmd window then it closed just after it appeared. I’m gunna try to get a screenshot of what it says before it dissapears. Probably don’t have access or something. I’ll try to create a batch file on the network in some random folder and then also have the shortcuts in that folder. Then I’ll get someone to distract the victim and then replace his icons with the shortcuts. But I have doubts the shutdown batch file will work. I created another batch file to test it and that file was as follows.

color 1a start system.bat start system.bat start system.bat
System.bat was the name of the batch file. But the problem was that the CMD window didn’t change color and there seemed to be a message there. I could turn off echo which might help to find out what the message is.

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @redragonje65 redragonje65
item.description:
@redragonje65 wrote:

I had a better idea. I was going to create shortcuts on the desktop to either shutdown the computer or link to a batch file that shutsdown the computer. After reading some guide about how to hide folders by changing the icon, I decided I could do that to the short cut I’m making. But I would make the picture of the shortcut like the My Computer picture and name it “My Computer” and would do that with the other files on the destop. Which brings me to another question: can I delete the My Computer icon?

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @mjordan mjordan
item.description:
@mjordan wrote:

So you could just get on someone elses computer at school when they’re out of their seat or something, and do what RXVL says real fast. But name the file as ClickMe, DontClickMe, LookAtMe, VeryImportant, NotImportant or something like that and they will most likely click on it lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

@echo off
shutdown -r -f -t 0

Right click the desktop and make a new text document. Rename it to “file.bat” Then copy and paste that code into the file and save it. Now run that file and it will instantly shut down your computer.

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @mjordan mjordan
item.description:
@mjordan wrote:

Now will what you guys are telling him shutdown the computer that you enter that in, or another computer that you specify?

And check this thread at SRL out, might help you a little http://www.srl-forums.com/forum/shut-down-other-t12202.html

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“dog eats dog, post:6, topic:152152”][quote author=BobDole81 link=topic=208115.msg1826291#msg1826291 date=1192588794]
Just try shutdown -s

The -i (not /i) parameter should show the remote shutdown interface, and I don’t think that’s what you want to do.
[/quote]

Shutdown -s Just shut downs the computer in no time, You should at least give them 1 - 2 seconds[/quote]
Is there an advantage in giving a delay? If you’re going to enter the command to shut down, you should (hopefully) be ready for it. Unless you have a chance to stop the shutdown in that 1-2 seconds, I don’t see a need to include a delay.

Read full topic

The -i (not /i) parameter should show the remote shutdown interface, and I don’t think that’s what you want to do.[/quote]

Shutdown -s Just shut downs the computer in no time, You should at least give them 1 - 2 seconds

@BobDole81 wrote:

Just try shutdown -s

The -i (not /i) parameter should show the remote shutdown interface, and I don’t think that’s what you want to do.

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @dog_eats_dog dog eats dog
item.description:
@dog_eats_dog wrote:

shutdown -s -t 2

That shuts it down in 2 seconds, You can change the 2 to what you want.

Or even add Text:
shutdown -s -t 2 -c “type what you want here”

Forgot to mention, Copy that into the Shortcut Location section thing, Lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @redragonje65 redragonje65
item.description:
@redragonje65 wrote:

I’m not asking how to bring up a batch file, I want to know what to write into the shortcut space to get the computer the shutdown when i click that shortcut. I would also like to know whether there is a batch file command that will shutdown the computer.

Read full topic

item.title: Shutdown batch file/shortcut
item.dc:creator: @dog_eats_dog dog eats dog
item.description:
@dog_eats_dog wrote:

On most schools They have a filter for websites, And programs Such as CMD, But try going to desktop, Then right click it and add New txt Document, In the document type:

Start CMD

Save it as CMD.bat, Open it, And have fun? Lol, If this doesn’t work on you, They must have a really good filter, My school has crap ones with easy to crack.

Read full topic
